This object represents the metrics for this Link as defined in [Tables 6-18, 6-20/IEEE1905.1].
If true then IEEE 802.1 Bridge(s) were detected between the local interface and the 1905.1 Neighbor.
[StatsCounter32] Estimated number of lost Packets sent to the Neighbor on this Link during a measurement period.
[StatsCounter32] Estimated number of lost Packets received from the Neighbor on this Link during a measurement period.
[StatsCounter32] Estimated number of Packets sent to the Neighbor on this Link, in the same measurement period used to estimate PacketErrors.
[StatsCounter32] Estimated number of Packets received from this Neighbor on this Link, in the same measurement period used to estimate PacketErrors.
The maximum MAC throughput in Mb/s between this Interface and the Neighbor on thisLink that is estimated at this Interface.
The estimated average percent of time that this Link is idle.
The Physical Layer (PHY) rate in Mb/s between this Interface and the Neighbor on thisLink that is estimated at this Interface.

The estimated Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI) ratio in db between this Interface and the Neighbor on this Link that is estimated at the receive side of this Interface.Note: This parameter is valid only for IEEE 802.11 Neighbors.
This object represents the rules to forward PDUs between interfaces within the 1905.1 Abstraction Layer.
The number of entries in the ForwardingRule table.
The 1905.1 fowarding rule as defined in [subclause 5 Abstraction Layer Management/IEEE1905.1].

Result parameter indicating the list of interfaces to which a frame satisfying the following classification rule should be forwarded. Commaseparated list (maximum length 2048) of strings(maximum length 256). Each list item MUST be the path name of an object, which MUST be a row of an Interface object. If the referenced item is deleted, the corresponding item MUST be removed from the list.
[MACAddress] Classification criterion. The destination MAC address. An empty string indicates this criterion is not used for classification.

If false, the classification includes only those frames that match theMACDestinationAddress entry, if specified. If true, the classification includes all frames except those that match the MACDestinationAddress entry, if specified.
[MACAddress] Classification criterion. The source MAC address. An empty string indicates this criterion is not used for classification.

If false, the classification includes only those frames that match theMACSourceAddress entry, if specified. If true, the classification includes all frames except those that match the MACSourceAddress entry, if specified.
Classification criterion. Ether Type Field in a frame. A value of -1 indicates this criterion is not used for classification.

If false, the classification includes only those frames that match the EtherType entry, if specified. If true, the classification includes all frames except those that match the EtherTypeentry, if specified.
Classification criterion. IEEE 802.1Q VLAN ID in a frame. A value of -1 indicates this criterion is not used for classification.
If false, the classification includes only those frames that match the Vid entry, if specified. If true, the classification includes all frames except those that match the Vid entry, if specified.
Classification criterion. IEEE 802.1Q Priority Code Point field. A value of -1 indicates this criterion is not used for classification.
If false, the classification includes only those frames that match the PCP entry, if specified. If true, the classification includes all frames except those that match the PCP entry, if specified.
This object represents the 1905.1 Network Topology capabilities of this device.

Enables or disables the 1905.1 Network Topology capabilities of device. When set totrue, the device clears and (re)populates the IEEE1905Device and ChangeLog tables. When set to false, the contents of the IEEE1905Device and ChangeLog tables are implementation specific.

When Enable is set to true, this parameter indicates the transient phase of the discovery of the NetworkTopology. Incomplete (Indicates that the device is populating the topology object during the transient phase) Available (Indicates that the transient phase is over and the device is maintaining and updating the topology object as changes occur) Error_Misconfigured (Indicates that a necessary configuration value is undefined or invalid).
The maximum number of entries allowed in the ChangeLog table.

The value MUST be the path name of a row in the ChangeLog table. If the referenced object is deleted, the parameter value MUST be set to an empty string. If the ChangeLogis modified the parameter is modified to reflect the last entry added to the ChangeLog.
The number of entries in the IEEE1905Device table.
The number of entries in the ChangeLog table.

This object represents log entries for changes in the 1905.1 Network Topology. The Change Log is a First In First Out queue where the oldest entries (defined by values of the TimeStamp parameter) are deleted once the log is full.
Date and Time at which the entry was added to the ChangeLog table.
Type of event for this entry. Enumeration of: NewNeighbor (Entry represents a discovery of a Neighbor) LostNeighbor (Entry represents the loss of a Neighbor).
[MACAddress] 1905.1 AL MAC Address of device which reported the change.
[MACAddress] MAC Address of the interface of the reporting device on which the change has been detected.
Type of Neighbor for this event. Enumeration of: IEEE1905 Non-IEEE1905

[MACAddress] MAC Address of the Neighbor of this event. If the value of the EventTypeparameter is NewNeighbor, then the value represents the MAC Address of new Neighbor that joined the network; if the value of the EventType parameter isLostNeighbor, then the value represents the MAC Address of Neighbor that left the network. If value of the NeighborType parameter is IEEE1905, then this value of this parameter is the 1905.1 AL MAC Address of the Neighbor.

This object represents log entries for changes in the 1905.1 Network Topology. The Change Log is a First In First Out queue where the oldest entries (defined by values of the TimeStamp parameter) are deleted once the log is full.

Security setup method for the network. Enumeration of: UCPK (User Configured Passphrase or Key) PBC (Push Button Configuration)
1905.1 common password for generating security keys. When read, this parameter returns an empty string, regardless of the actual value.
Top level object for dynamically managed software applications.

This flag can be set by local management system or remote management. When set to true, preinstalled software modules in the firmware need to be processed. If this flag is true and X_BROADCOM_COM_PreinstallAtRuntime is true, preinstall process will take place at runtime. Otherwise, preinstall process will take place after reboot
This flag provides the information whether preinstall package process should happen at runtime or bootup time

This parameter sets the mode that dictates the behavior of how software modules are installed from a firmware. When this flag is true, the packages in the firmware will overwrite all preinstalled EE(s) and all DUs installed in it whether they were manually installed or preinstalled from firmware update. When false, if there are existing preinstalled packages, they are not overwritten until the existing packages are removed (configuration reset to default).
This parameter is the maximum number of deployment units which openplat project can install. If the value is -1, it means no limitation.

Describe an Execution Environment that is available on the device along with its configurable settings. At most one entry in this table can exist with a given value for Alias, or with a given value for Name.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_Baseline:1, SM_ExecEnvs:1

Indicateds whether or not this ExecEnv is enabled.
Disabling an enabled Execution Environment stops it, while enabling a disabled Execution Environment starts it.
When an Execution Environment is disabled, Deployment Units installed to that Execution Environment will be unaffected, but any Execution Units currently running on that Execution Environment will automatically transition to Idle.
If a ChangeDUState is attempted on a DeploymentUnit that is to be applied against a disabled ExecEnv, that ChangeDUState operation fails and the associated DUStateChangeComplete RPC will contain a FaultStruct for that operation.
If a SetParameterValues is attempted against the ExecutionUnit.{i}.RequestedState for an ExecutionUnit that is associated with a disabled ExecEnv a CWMP Fault will be issued in response.
Disabling an Execution Environment could place the device in a non-manageable state that would require a manual reboot to alleviate. For example, if the operating system itself was modeled as an ExecEnv and the ACS disabled it, the CWMP managment agent might be terminated leaving the device unmanageable.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_ExecEnvs:1, SM_Baseline:1
Indicates the status of this ExecEnv. Enumeration of: Up Error (OPTIONAL) Disabled
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_ExecEnvs:1, SM_Baseline:1

Setting this parameter to true causes EE to revert back to the state it was in when it first issued a "1 BOOTSTRAP" inform event. The following requirement indicate what the MUST happen for the reset to be complete:
1. Al DUs that were installed after the first "1 BOOTSTRAP" Inform event MUST be removed. 2. All persistent storage, configuration files, and log files that were associated with the removed DUs MUST be removed 3. Any DU that is still installed against the EE MUST be restored to the version present when the first "1 BOOTSTRAP" Inform evnet was issued. 4. Any DU that was present when the last "1 BOOTSTRAP" Inform event was issued, but was subsequently uninstalled and is now not present, MUST be installed with the version that was present when the last "1 BOOTSTRAP" inform event was issued 5. The EE MUST be restored to the version and conifguration present when the first "1 BOOTSTRAP" Inform event was issued 6. The EE MUST be restarted after all other restoration requirements have been met.
When read, this parameter returns false, regardless of the actual value.

A non-volatitle handle used to reference this instance. Alias provides a mechanism for an ACS to label this instance for future reference.
An initial unique value MUST be assigned when the CPE creates an instance of this ExecEnv.
A Name provided by the CPE that adequately distinguishes this ExecEnv from all other ExecEnv instances.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_ExecEnvs:1, SM_Baseline:1
Indicates the complete type and specification version of this ExecEnv
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_ExecEnvs:1, SM_Baseline:1

The run level that this ExecEnv will be in upon startup (whether that is caused by a CPE Boot or the Execution Envionment starting).
Run levels dictate which Execution Units will be started. Execution Units will be started if ExecutionUnit.{i}.RunLevel is less than CurrentRunLevel and ExecutionUnit.{i}.AutoStart is true.
If the value of CurrentRunLevel is -1, then the value of this parameter is irrelevant when read and setting its value has no impact to the Run Level of this ExecEnv.

Provides a mechanism to remotely manipulate the run level of this ExecEnv.
Run levels dictate which Execution Units will be started if ExecutionUnit.{i}.RunLevel is less than CurrentRunLevel and ExecutionUnit.{i}.AutoStart is true.
Setting this value when CurrentRunLevel is -1 has no impact to the Run Level of this ExecEnv.
When read, this parameter retuns -1, regardless of the actual value.

The run level that this ExecEnv is currently operating in.
Upon startup (whether that is caused by a CPE Boot or the Execution Environment starting), Current Run Level will be equal to InitialRunLevel, unless Run Levels are not supported by this ExecEnv in which case CurrentRunLevel will be -1.
Run level dictate which Execution Units will be started. Execution United will be started if ExecutionUnit.{i}.RunLevel is less than CurrentRunLevel and ExecutionUnit.{i}.AutoSatrt is true.
If CurrentRunLevel is -1 then RunLevels are not suported by this ExecEnv and setting InitialRunLevel or RequestedRunLevel will not impact the Run Level of this ExecEnv.

Indicates the initial value on creation for {{param|#.ExecutionUnit.{i}.RunLevel}} for all Execution Unit instances associated with this {{object}}. If the value of {{param|CurrentRunLevel}} is -1, then the value of this parameter is irrelevant when read and setting its value has no impact on the Run Level of any Execution Unit.
The vendor that produced this ExecEnv.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_ExecEnvs:1, SM_Baseline:1
The version of this ExecEnv as specified by the Vendor that implemented this ExecEnv, not the version of the specification.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_ExecEnvs:1, SM_Baseline:1

The value MUST be the path name of a row in the ExecEnv table. If the referenced object is deleted, the parameter value MUST be set to an empty string. Represents the parent ExecEnv of this ExecEnv.
If this value is an empty string then this is the Primary Execution Environment.
The amount of disk space measured in kilobytes allocated to this ExecEnv. A value of -1 MUST be used for ExecEnv instances where this parameter is not applicable.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_ExecEnvs:1

The amount of disk space measured in kilobytes currently available ito this ExecEnv. This value changes as the ExecutionUnit instances assocatated with this ExecEnv consumes disk space. A value of 1 MUST be used for ExecEnv isntances where this parameter is not applicable.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_ExecEnvs:1
The amount of physical RAM measured in kilobytes allocated to this ExecEnv. A value of -1 MUST be used for ExecEnv instances where this paremter is not applicable.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_ExecEnvs:1

The amount of physcial RAM measured in kilobytes currrently available to this ExecEnv. This value changes as the Execution Unit instances associated with this ExecEnv are started/stopped and consume the physical RAM. A value of -1 MUST be used for ExecEnv instances where this parameter is not applicable.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_ExecEnvs:1

Comma-separated list of strings. Eac list item MUST be the path name of a rows in the ExecutionUnit table. If the referenced object is deleted, the corresponding item MUST be removed from the list Represents the ExecutionUnit instances currently running on this ExecEnv. This is a subset of AssociatedExecutionUnits as it only contains ExecutionUnit instances that are currently Active.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_ExecEnvs:1, SM_Baseline:1

Comma-separted list of strings. Each list item MUST be the path name of a row in the DeviceInfo.Processor table. If the referenced object is deleted, the corresponding item MUST be removed from the list. Represents the processor that this ExecEnv has available to it.
The EID of the app that manages this Execution Environment.
The container name of this Execution Environment.
The manager application name of this Execution Environment, if this EE is a app_mediaType is 'ee_tarball'. It is named as app_tarballMngrExecutable in the package information text file.
When this flag is true, this EE has been preinstalled by BEEP framework.
The unique username of this ExecEnv. Only need for unprivileged container.
The base uid of this ExecEnv. Only need for unprivileged container.
List of IPv4 addresses of this ExecEnv delimited by comma.
List of IPv6 addresses of this ExecEnv delimited by comma.

For each execution environment, this parameter sets the maximum number of active containers in the EE. It is up to EE manager to maintain this limit. -1 means unlimited number of active containers as long as the EE's resource allows it.
This parameter is the number of current active containers in the execution environment. It is up to EE manager to update this number.
This object contains proprietary information from the manifest of this ExecEnv.
When 0, EE is an unprivileged container. When 1, EE is a privileged container without write permission to proc/sys. When 2, EE is a privileged container with write permission to proc/sys.

When true, EE will start after being installed. This parameter takes precedence over the object's Enable parameter which is default to be false. When it is desirable to start the EE immediately after installation, set this parameter to true. Consequently, the EE's enable parameter is set to true as well.
This parameter is only used for unprivileged EEs. When 0, the unprivileged EE cannot access any file in host filesystem. When 1, the unprivileged EE is allowed to access the files in host filesystem.
This parameter specifies those ports requested by the EE. The format is port/tcp, port/udp, port with the default protocol being tcp if not specified.
Message bus attribute section of this EE.

The bus info string contains the message bus information of this EE. It is string parameters seperated by | with first parameter being busType. For example, D-Bus info will be like "D-Bus|com.broadcom.pmd|/com/broadcom/pmd|com.broadcom.pmd"
Process attribute section of this EE.
The name of the profile that defines this EE's AppArmor confinement.

Arguments to start this EE process. List of strings with similar semantics to IEEE Std 1003.1-2008 execvp's argv.
This specification extends the IEEE standard in that at least one entry is REQUIRED, and that entry is used with the same semantics as execvp's file.
For example, to start BEE process with command "pmd", argv[0]="pmd"
Process argv, e.g. "pmd"
Arguments to set this EE process's environment variables.
Process' environment variables
Directories to be mounted into EE containers
Destination of mount point: path inside container. This value MUST be an absolute path. This parameter is required for Mounts object

A device name, but can also be a file or directory name for bind mounts or a dummy. Path values for bind mounts are either absolute or relative to the bundle. This parameter is optional for Mounts object
The type of the filesystem to be mounted. This parameter is optional for Mounts object
Mount options of the filesystem to be used. This dynamic object is optional for Mounts object
Mount options of the filesystem to be used
Linux attribute section of this EE.
Resource attributes for this EE.
Block I/O device attributes.
Block IO type.
Device major number.
Device minor number.
For BPS device type, the maximum read/write rate in bytes per second on the device. For IOPS device type, the maximum number of read/write operations per second on the device.
Resource CPU attributes.
Specifies the total amount of time in microseconds for which all tasks in a cgroup can run during one period. The period is fixed at 100 milliseconds. Minimum quota is 1 millisecond.
Specifies a period of time in microseconds for the longest continuous period in which the tasks in a cgroup have access to CPU resources. Applicable to real-time scheduling tasks only.
Comma-separated list of CPUs with dashes ("-") to represent ranges, the container will run in. For example, "0-2,16" represents CPUs 0, 1, 2, and 16.
Resource device attributes.
When true, allow access to device. Otherwise, cannot access to device.
Type of device: a(all), c(char), or b(block). Default to a(all).
Device major number.
Device minor number.
Cgroup permissions for device. A composition of r(read), w(write), and m(mknod). For example, "rwm".
Network setup attributes.

Disconnect (default): No network setup required (No LAN nor WAN access). Primary: LAN and WAN access available. Secondary: WAN access available. LAN RX only, no TX. LanOnly: LAN access only. WanOnly: WAN access only.
List of devices that must be available in the container.
Full path to device inside container.
Type of Linux device: c, b, u or p. More info in mknod(1).
Device major number.
Device minor number.
Container hooks.
List of container presetup hooks.
Full path to the hook command.
Timeout value in seconds for running hook command.
Hook command argv[].
Hook command argv.
List of container prestart hooks.
Full path to the hook command.
Timeout value in seconds for running hook command.
Hook command argv[].
Hook command argv.
List of container poststart hooks.
Full path to the hook command.
Timeout value in seconds for running hook command.
Hook command argv[].
Hook command argv.
List of container poststop hooks.
Full path to the hook command.
Timeout value in seconds for running hook command.
Hook command argv[].

this table serves as the Deployment Unit inventory and contains status information about each Deployment Unit.
A new instance of this table gets created during the installation of a Software Module.
At most one entry in this table can exist with all the same values for UUID, Version and ExecutionEnvRef, or with a given value for Alias.

The TR181 spec says this object is Read-only, i.e. multiple instances. I think we can change it back since only osgid and linmosd will create instances of this object, not tr69c. REPORT_PROFILE: SM_Baseline:1, SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1

A universally Unique Identifier chosen by the ACS. The format of this valued defined by RFC4122 Version 4 (Random)
This value MUST NOT be altered when the DeploymentUnit is updated.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1
Deployment Unit Identifier chosen by targed ExecEnv. The formate of this value is Execution Environment specific.

A non-volatile handle used to reference this instance. Alias provides a mechanism for an ACS to label this instance for furture reference.
An initial unique value MUST be assigned when the CPE creates an instance of this DeploymentUnit.
Indicates the Name of this DeploymentUnit, which is choosen by the author of the Deployment Unit.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1

Indicates the status of this DeploymentUnit. Enumeration of: Installing (this instance is in the process of being Installed and SHOULD transition to the Installed state) Installed (this instance has been successfully installed. The Resolved flag SHOULD also be referenced for dependency resolution) Updating (this instance is in the process of being updated and SHOULD transition to the Installed state) Uninstalling (this instance is in the process of being Uninstalled and should be transition to the Uninstalled state) Uninstalled (this instance has been successfully Uninstalled. This status will typically not be seen within a DeploymentUnit instance)
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1
Indicates whether or not this DeploymentUnit has resolved all of its dependencies.

Contains the URL used by the most recent ChangeDUState RPC to either Install or Update this DeploymentUnit.

Username to be used by the CPE to authenticate with the file server, if authentication is required.
Password to be used by the CPE to authenticate with the file server, if authentication is required.
Textual description of this DeploymentUnit. The format of this value is Execution Environment specific.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1
Vendor of this DeploymentUnit.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1
Version of this DeploymentUnit.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1

Comma-separated list of strings. Each list item MUST be the path name of a table row in the DeviceInfo.VendorLogFile table. If the referenced object is deleted, the corresponding item MUST be removed from the list. Represents the vendor log files that have come into existence because of this ExecutionUnit.
When the DeploymentUnit (that caused this ExecutionUnit to come into existence) is uninstalled the vendor log files referenced here SHOLD be removed from the CPE.
Not all DeploymentUnit instances will actually have a corresponding vendor log file in which case the value of this parameter will be an empty string.

Comma-separated list of strings. Each list item MUST be the path name of a table row in the DeviceInfo.VendorConfigFile table. If the referenced object is deleted, the corresponding item MUST be removed from the list. Represents the vendor config files that have come into existence because of this ExecutionUnit.
When the DeploymentUnit (that caused this ExecutionUnit to come into existence) is uninstalled the vendor config files referenced here SHOULD be removed from the CPE.
Not all DeploymentUnit instances will actually have a corresponding vendor config file in which case the value of this parameter will be an empty string.

Comma-separated list of strings. Each list item MUST be the path name of a row in the ExecutionUnit table. If the referenced object is deleted, the corresponding item MUST be removed from the list. Represents the ExecutionUnit instances that are associated with this DeploymentUnit instance.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1

This value MUST be the path name of a row in the ExecEnv table. If the referenced object is deleted, the parameter value MUST be set to an empty string. Represents the ExecEnv that this DeploymentUnit is associated with.
Should be ExecutionEnvRef. When is a good time to fix? REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1

Comma-separated list of strings. Each list item MUST be the path name of a row in the ExecEnv table. If the referenced object is deleted, the corresponding item MUST be removed from the list. Represents the ExecEnv instances that are associated with this DeploymentUnit instance.
The date and time the operation on the DU was started in UTC. If this is unknown, the parameter value is set to the Unknow Time value.
The date and time the operation on the DU was completed in UTC. If this is unknown, the parameter value is set to the Unknow Time value.
This field is only used when this DU is associated with OSGI/Felix.
When this flag is true, this DU has been preinstalled by BEEP framework.

This table serves as the Execution Unit inventory and contains both status information about each Execution Unit as well as configurable parameters for each Execution Unit.
Each DeploymentUnit that is installed can have zero or more Execution Units.
Once a Deployment Unit is installed, it populates this table with its contained Execution Units.
When the Deployment Unit (that caused this ExecutionUnit to come into existence) is updated, this instance MAY be removed and new instances MAY come into existence. While the Deployment Unit (that caused this ExecutionUnit to come into existence) is being updated, all ExecutionUnit instances assocciatedwith the Deployment Unit will be stopped until the update is complete at which time they will be restored to the state that they were in before the update started.
When the Deployment Unit (that caused this ExecutionUnit to come into existence) is uninstalled, this instance is removed.
Each ExecutionUnit MAY also contain a set of vendor specific parameters displaying status and maining configuration that reside under the Extensions objection.
At most one entry in this table can exist with a given value for EUID or with a given value for Alias.

The TR181 spec says this object is Read-only, i.e. multiple instances. I think we can change it back since only osgid and linmosd will create instances of this object, not tr69c. REPORT_PROFILE: SM_Baseline:1, SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1

Execution Unit Identifier chosen by the ExecEnv during installation of the associated DeploymentUnit.
The format of this value is Execution Environment specific, but it MUST be unique across ExecEnv isntances. Thus, it is recommended that this be a combination of the ExecEnv.{i}.Name and and ExecutionEnvironment local unique value.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1

A non-volatile handle used to reference this instance. Alias provides a mechanism for an ACS to label this instance for future reference.
An initial unique value MUST be assigned when the CPE creates an instance of this ExecutionUnit.
The name of this ExecutionUnit as it pertains to its associated DeploymentUnit, which SHOULD be unique accross all ExecutionUnit instances contained within its associated DeploymentUnit.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1
The name of this ExecutionUnit as provided by the ExecEnv, which SHOULD be unique across all ExecutionUnit intances contained within a specif ExecEnv.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1

Indicates the status of this Execution Unit. Enumeration of: Idle (this instance is in an Idle state and not running) Starting (this instance is in the process of Starting and SHOULD transition to the Active state) Active (this instance is currently running) Stopping (this instance is in the process of Stopping and SHOULD transition to the Idle state)
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1

Indicates the state transition that the ACS is requesting for this ExecutionUnit. Enumeration of: Idle (if this ExcutionUnit is currently Starting or Active, the CPE will attempt to Stop the Execution Unit; otherwise this requested state is ignored)
Active (if this ExecutionUnit is currently in Idle the CPE will attempt to Start the ExcutionUnit. If this ExecutionUnit is in Stopping the request is rejected and a fault is raised. Otherwise, this request state is ignored)
When read, this parameter returns an empty string, regardless of the actual value.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1

If while running or transitioning between states tis ExecutionUnit identifies a fault this parameter embodies the problem. The value of NoFault MUST be used when everything is working as intended. Enumeration of: NoFault FailureOnStart FaiureOnAutoStart FailureOnStop FailureWhileActive DependencyFailure UnStartable
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1

If while running or transitioning between states this ExecutionUnit identifies a fault this pareamter provides a more detailed explaination of the problem.
If ExecutionFaultCode has the value of NoFault then the value of this parameter MUST be an empty string and ignored by ACS.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1
This parameter indicates the reason of the state change of the EU. So far, only out of memory is supported.
This parameter records the time at which the state of the EU changes.

Controls whether or not this ExecutionUnit will automatically start when its ExecEnv is either booted or restarted.
If TRUE and the RunLevel verification is also met, then this ExecutionUnit will be automatically started by the device after a reboot or restart.
If false this ExecutionUnit will not be started after a reboot or restart until it is explicitly commanded to do so either by the ACS or another Execution Unit.

Determines when this ExecutionUnit will be started.
If AutoStart is true and ExecEnv.{i}.CurrentRunLevel is greater than RunLevel, then this ExecutionUnit will be started.
If the value of ExecEnv.{i}.CurrentRunLevel is -1, the the associated ExecEnv. doesn't support Run Levels, thus the value of this parameter is irrelvant when read and setting its value has no impact to the Run Level of this ExecutionUnit.
Vendor of this ExecutionUnit.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1
Version of this ExecutionUnit. The format of this value is Execution Environment specific.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1
Textual description of this ExecutionUnit. The format of this value is Execution Environment specific.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1
The amount of disk space measured in kilobytes currently being used by this ExecutionUnit. A valued of -1 MUST be used for ExecutionUnit instances where this parameter is not applicable.
The amount of physical RAM measured in kilobytes currently being used by this ExecutionUnit. A valued of -1 MUST be used for ExecutionUnit instances where this parameter is not applicable.

Comma-separated list of strings. Each list item MUST be the path name of a table row. If the referenced object is deleted, the corresponding item MUST be removed from the list. Represnts the instances of multi-instanced object that have come into existence because of this ExecutionUnit.
NOTE: All other objects and parameters (i.e. not multi-instanced objects) that this Execution has caused to come into existence will be discovered via the DeviceInfo.SupportedDataModel.{i}.table.

Comma-separated list of strings. Each list item MUST be the path name of a table row in the DeviceInfo.ProcessStatus.Process table. If the referenced object is deleted, the corresponding item MUST be removed from the list. Represents the system processes that are active in the system because of this ExecutionUnit.
If Status is not Active it is expected that this list will be an empty string. Some ExecutionUnit instances MIGHT NOT have any system processes irrespective of the value of Status.

Comma-separated list of strings. Each list item MUST be the path name of a table row in the DeviceInfo.VendorLogFile table. If the referenced object is deleted, the corresponding item MUST be removed from the list. Represents the vendor log files that have come into existence because of this ExecutionUnit.
When the DeploymentUnit (that caused this ExecutionUnit to come into existence) is uninstalled the vendor log files referenced here SHOLD be removed from the CPE.
Not all ExecutionUnit instances will actually have a corresponding vendor log file in which case the value of this parameter will be an empty string.

Comma-separated list of strings. Each list item MUST be the path name of a table row in the DeviceInfo.VendorConfigFile table. If the referenced object is deleted, the corresponding item MUST be removed from the list. Represents the vendor config files that have come into existence because of this ExecutionUnit.
When the DeploymentUnit (that caused this ExecutionUnit to come into existence) is uninstalled the vendor config files referenced here SHOULD be removed from the CPE.
Not all ExecutionUnit instances will actually have a corresponding vendor config file in which case the value of this parameter will be an empty string.

The value MUST be the path name of a table row in the DeviceInfo.SupportedDataModel table. If the referenced object is deleted, this parameter value MUST be set to an empty string. Represents the CWMP-DT schema instance that has been introduced to this device because of existence of this ExecutionUnit.

This value MUST be the path name of a row in the ExecEnv table. If the referenced object is deleted, the parameter value MUST be set to an empty string. Represents the ExecEnv that this ExecutionUnit is associated with.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1
This field is only used when this EU is associated with OSGI/Felix.
The digital digest of this app -- ie. binary executable application digest which will be checked againt during the launch.
The digital digest of this app manifest which will be checked againt during app launch.
The media type of this EU - "executible and tarball" for now and can be expanded if needed.
The unique username of this Execution Unit.
The manager application name of this Execution Unit, if this a app_mediaType 'tarball'. It is named as app_tarballMngrExecutable in the package information text file.
List of IPv4 addresses of this EU delimited by comma.
List of IPv6 addresses of this EU delimited by comma.

The auto-start order of this EU. After its ExecEnv is either rebooted or restarted, EUs with autoStartOrder 0 will be auto-started first, followed by EUs with autoStartOrder 1, provided that the EU is autoStart enabled and the RunLevel verification is also met.

Controls whether or not this ExecutionUnit will automatically restart after it exits.
If TRUE this ExecutionUnit will be restarted by the device unless it was stopped by ACS or other management interface.
If false this ExecutionUnit will not be restarted after it exits.
The maximum number of tries to restart this ExecutionUnit after it exits.
The device MUST wait for the interval (in milliseconds) specified by this parameter to expire before attempting to restart this ExecutionUnit.

The device MUST check that the ExecutionUnit remains running after the period (in milliseconds) specified by this parameter.
If it is, then this should be taken as an indication that the ExecutionUnit is running successfully
and at this point the device MUST reset the current number of retries to zero.
The current number of tries for restarting the ExecutionUnit.
The container name of this ExecutionUnit.

This object proposes a general location for vendor extensions specific to this Execution Unit, which allows multiple Execution Units to expose parameters without the concern of conflicting parameter names. These vendor extensions are related to displaying status and maintaining configuration for this Execution Unit.
It is also possible for the Execution Unit to expose status and configuration parameters within Service objects or as embedded objects and parameters directly within the root data model, in which case the cobination of References and SupportedDataModelRef will be used to determine their locations.
REPORT_PROFILE: SM_DeployAndExecUnits:1, SM_Baseline:1

This object contains property information of execution unit running on BEEP D-Bus framework.

This object contains bus client application information of execution unit running on BEEP D-Bus framework.
This value is the name of D-Bus client application.
The number of entries in the Bus Client Privilege table.

This object contains client privilege information of execution unit running on BEEP D-Bus framework. The client application represented by this execution unit is allowed to access to services that are configured by this object.
This value is the bus wellknown name of D-Bus application.
This value is the object path of D-Bus application.
This value is the interface of D-Bus application.
This value is name of either method, signal, or property of D-Bus application.
This value specifies type of member. It is either All, Method, Signal, or Property.
This object contains proprietary information from the manifest of this execution unit.
This value indicates whether D-Bus application is run on priviledged or unpriviledged container.
Container Memory size limit in Kbytes. -1 for unlimited memory size.
Container flash size limit in Kbytes. -1 for unlimited flash size.

Disconnect (default): No network setup required (No LAN nor WAN access). Primary: LAN and WAN access available. Secondary: WAN access available. LAN RX only, no TX. LanOnly: LAN access only. WanOnly: WAN access only.
Interface identifier is used for lanonly networking mode
This parameter specifies those ports requested by the EU service. The format is port/tcp, port/udp, port with the default protocol being tcp if not specified.
Specifies a period of time in microseconds for the longest continuous period in which the tasks in a cgroup have access to CPU resources. Applicable to real-time scheduling tasks only.
Comma-separated list of CPUs with dashes ("-") to represent ranges, the container will run in. For example, "0-2,16" represents CPUs 0, 1, 2, and 16.
Message bus attribute section of this EU.

The bus info string contains the message bus information of this EE. It is string parameters seperated by | with first parameter being busType. For example, D-Bus info will be like "D-Bus|com.broadcom.pmd|/com/broadcom/pmd|com.broadcom.pmd"
Process attribute section of this EU.
The name of the profile that defines this EU's AppArmor confinement.

Arguments to start this EU process. List of strings with similar semantics to IEEE Std 1003.1-2008 execvp's argv.
This specification extends the IEEE standard in that at least one entry is REQUIRED, and that entry is used with the same semantics as execvp's file.
For example, to start cwmpd process with command "cwmpd -v 0", argv[0]="cwmpd", argv[1]="-v", argv[2]="0"
Process argv, e.g. "cwmp".
Arguments to set this EU process's environment variables.
Process' environment variables
Directories to be mounted into EU containers
Destination of mount point: path inside container. This value MUST be an absolute path. This parameter is required for Mounts object

A device name, but can also be a file or directory name for bind mounts or a dummy. Path values for bind mounts are either absolute or relative to the bundle. This parameter is optional for Mounts object
The type of the filesystem to be mounted. This parameter is optional for Mounts object
Mount options of the filesystem to be used. This dynamic object is optional for Mounts object
Mount options of the filesystem to be used

List of dependencies that this EU depends on.
Comma-separated list of libraries that this EU depends on.
Seccomp attributes.
The default action for seccomp rules. Valid values are defined in SyscallActionValues array.
Seccomp syscalls attributes.

The action for seccomp rules. Valid values are defined in SyscallActionValues array.

Each instance of this table represents an MDM granular access.

This object contains general information related to managing security features on the device.
The number of entries in the Certificate table.
This table provides information about all types of public key-based credentials, such as X.509 certificates, see {{bibref|RFC5280}}.
Enables or disables this certificate.
The last modification time of this certificate.
The Serial Number field in an X.509 certificate, see {{bibref|RFC5280}}.
The Issuer field in an X.509 certificate, see {{bibref|RFC5280}}; i.e. the Distinguished Name (DN) of the entity who has signed the certificate.
The beginning of the certificate validity period; i.e. the Not Before field in an X.509 certificate, see {{bibref|RFC5280}}.
The end of the certificate validity period; i.e., the Not After field in an X.509 certificate, see {{bibref|RFC5280}}.
The Distinguished Name (DN) of the entity associated with the Public Key; i.e., the Subject field in an X.509 certificate, see {{bibref|RFC5280}}.
{{list}} Each item is a DNS Name. The Subject Alternative Names extension field in an X.509 certificate, see {{bibref|RFC5280}}.
The algorithm used in signing the certificate; i.e. the Signature Algorithm field in an X.509 certificate, see {{bibref|RFC5280}}.
Certificate name
Key to match with name parameter in X_BROADCOM_COM_CertificateCfg object

This object provides bulk data collection capabilities and global collection settings that affect the entire device. Bulk Data utilizes various solutions (e.g., IPDR, HTTP) to collect data from devices and transfer the data to a collection server. The IPDR solution is based on a service specification described in {{bibref|TR-232}}. The HTTP solution is based on transfer mechanisms described in {{template|BULK-DATA-HTTP-REF}}. {{template|BULK-DATA-OPT-SOLNS}} The Bulk Data Collection Profiles are measured over a reporting interval (which can be aligned with absolute time) and are made available to the collection server.
Enables or disables all collection profiles. If {{false}}, bulk data will not be collected or reported.
Indicates the status of the Bulk Data Collection mechanism.
Minimum reporting interval in seconds that the CPE is capable of supporting. A value of 0 indicates no minimum reporting interval.
Comma-separated list of strings. Represents the IPDR Protocols that this device is capable of supporting. Enumeration of: Streaming File HTTP USPEventNotif
Comma-separated list of strings. Represents the IPDR Encoding Types that this device is capable of supporting. Enumeration of: XML XDR CSV JSON
When true, the Device supports the use of wildcards to determine the parameters that are reported using a Profile.

The maximum number of profiles that can exist at any given time. Specifically, the maximum number of {{object|Profile.{i}.}} instances that the Controller can create. If the value of this parameter is -1, then it means that the CPE doesn't have a limit to the number of profiles that can exist.

The maximum number of parameters that can be referenced via the bulk data collection mechanism. Specifically, the maximum number of parameters that can be referenced via {{param|Profile.{i}.Parameter.{i}.Reference}} across all Profile and Parameter instances (including the expansion of partial paths within the Reference parameter). If the value of this parameter is -1, then it means that the CPE doesn't have a limit to the number of parameter that can be referenced via the bulk data collection mechanism.
The number of entries in the Profile table.

A set of Bulk Data Collection profiles. Each profile represents a bulk data report, including its own timing configuration, communications configuration, and set of parameters. This allows the Controller to configure multiple reports to be generated at different times for different sets of data.
Enables or disables this specific bulk data profile. If {{false}}, this profile will not be collected or reported.
A non-volatile handle used to reference this instance. Alias provides a mechanism for an ACS to label this instance for future reference.
The name of the profile.

{{reference|the {{object|Device.LocalAgent.Controller.}} instance that created or last updated this {{object}}}} The value of this parameter is automatically populated by the USP Agent upon {{object}} creation using the reference to the USP Controller that created the instance. The value of this parameter is automatically updated by the USP Agent upon {{object}} alteration using the reference to the USP Controller that changed the instance.

The number of failed reports to be retained and transmitted (in addition to the current report) at the end of the current reporting interval. If the value of the {{param|EncodingType}} parameter is modified any outstanding failed reports are deleted. If the CPE cannot retain the number of failed reports from previous reporting intervals while transmitting the report of the current reporting interval, then the oldest failed reports are deleted until the CPE is able to transmit the report from the current reporting interval. A value of 0 indicates that failed reports are not to be retained for transmission in the next reporting interval. A value of -1 indicates that the CPE will retain as many failed reports as possible.
The Bulk Data Protocol being used for this collection profile.
The Bulk Data encoding type being used for this collection profile.

The reporting interval in {{units}}. Each report is generated based on this interval and {{param|TimeReference}}. The CPE MAY reject a request to set {{param}} to less than {{param|#.MinReportingInterval}}. Reporting intervals MUST begin every {{param}} {{units}}. If {{param}} is changed while collection is enabled, the first reporting interval begins immediately. For example, if {{param}} is 86400 (a day) and if {{param|TimeReference}} is set to UTC midnight on some day (in the past, present, or future) then the CPE will generate (and transmit, if the {{param|Protocol}} parameter is set to {{enum|Streaming|#.Protocols}}) its report at midnight every 24 hours.

An absolute time reference in UTC to determine when will be transmitted. Each reporting interval MUST complete at this reference time plus or minus an integer multiple of {{param|ReportingInterval}}, unless unable to due to higher prioritized operations. {{param}} is used only to set the "phase" of the reporting intervals. The actual value of {{param}} can be arbitrarily far into the past or future. If {{param}} is changed while collection of bulk data is enabled, the first reporting interval begins immediately. The Unknown Time value as defined in {{bibref|TR-106}} indicates that no particular time reference is specified. That is, the CPE MAY locally choose the time reference, and is required only to adhere to the specified reporting intervals. If absolute time is not available to the CPE, its reporting interval behavior MUST be the same as if the {{param}} parameter was set to the Unknown Time value. For example, if {{param|ReportingInterval}} is 86400 (a day) and if {{param}} is set to UTC midnight on some day (in the past, present, or future) then the CPE will generate (and transmit, if in a "ITPush" mode) its report at midnight every 24 hours. Note that, if {{param}} is set to a time other than the Unknown Time, the first reporting interval (which has to begin immediately) will almost certainly be shorter than {{param|ReportingInterval}}). This is why {{param}} is defined in terms of when reporting intervals complete rather than start.

This is the host name or IP Address of the IPDR Collector to be used by the CPE to stream bulk data records if this collection profile is configured for the IPDR Streaming Protocol {{bibref|IPDR-SP}} (the {{param|Protocol}} parameter has a value of {{enum|Streaming|#.Protocols}}).

This is the port number of the IPDR Collector to be used by the CPE to stream bulk data records if this collection profile is configured for the IPDR Streaming Protocol {{bibref|IPDR-SP}} (the {{param|Protocol}} parameter has a value of {{enum|Streaming|#.Protocols}}).

This is the unique identification of an IPDR Session to be used when this collection profile is configured for the IPDR Streaming Protocol {{bibref|IPDR-SP}} (the {{param|Protocol}} parameter has a value of {{enum|Streaming|#.Protocols}}). A Controller MUST NOT configure multiple IPDR Streaming Protocol collection profiles with the same {{param}}. Doing so MUST cause the CPE to fail the SetParameterValues. Within the IPDR Streaming Protocol specification the Session ID has a type of a single 'char', but we are restricting the range even further (ASCII values of '0' - '9' and 'A' - 'Z'.

This is the {{datatype}} within the CPE that is used by an IPDR Collector to retrieve the IPDRDocs when this collection profile is configured for the IPDR File Transfer Protocol {{bibref|IPDR-FTP}} (the {{param|Protocol}} parameter has a value of {{enum|File|#.Protocols}}).

Username used for authentication of the {{param|FileTransferURL}}. This is the {{param}} that the IPDR Collector uses to access the CPE when this collection profile is configured for the IPDR File Transfer Protocol {{bibref|IPDR-FTP}} (the {{param|Protocol}} parameter has a value of {{enum|File|#.Protocols}}).

Password used for authentication of the {{param|FileTransferURL}}. This is the {{param}} that the IPDR Collector uses to access the CPE when this collection profile is configured for the IPDR File Transfer Protocol {{bibref|IPDR-FTP}} (the {{param|Protocol}} parameter has a value of {{enum|File|#.Protocols}}).

If this collection profile is configured for the IPDR File Transfer Protocol {{bibref|IPDR-FTP}} (the {{param|Protocol}} parameter has a value of {{enum|File|#.Protocols}}) then the control file names will be of the following format: :<ControlFilePrefix>_<ControlFilePolicy>.<ControlFileSuffix>Where the following rules apply: * ControlFilePrefix MUST NOT contain an underscore '_' or any other character not suitable for a file name.* ControlFilePolicy MUST contain one or more 'N' characters, where the number of 'N' characters denotes the number of digits in the sequence number, including leading zeros as necessary to match the number of 'N' characters. * ControlFileSuffix is a file extension.For example, BulkData_NNNN.log where "BulkData" would be the prefix, "NNNN" would be the policy, and "log" would be the suffix. Files adhering to this file format would look like: BulkData_0000.log, BulkData_0001.log, etc.
The number of entries in the Parameter table.
Bulk data parameter table. Each entry in this table represents a parameter (or set of parameters if a partial path is provided) to be collected and reported.

Name of the parameter in the report body. If the value of this parameter is {{empty}}, then the value of the {{param|Reference}} parameter is used as the name. When the value {{param|Reference}} parameter contains wildcards and/or partial parameter names, the rules for determining the value of this parameter are specified in {{template|BULK-DATA-WILD-REF}}.

Represents the parameter(s) that are part of this Bulk Data collection profile. In the case where a partial parameter path is specified all sub-objects and contained parameters will be part of the bulk data collected and reported. If the path name refers to an object then it MUST end with a '.'.
This object defines the properties to be used when the Profile object's EncodingType parameter value is CSV.
Field separator to use when encoding CSV data.
Row separator to use when encoding CSV data.
Escape character to use when encoding CSV data.

This parameter describes the formatting used for reports defined by this profile as described in [Annex A.2.4/TR-369].
Note: This parameter is encoded as a token in the BBF-Report-Format header field and MUST NOT include spaces or other characters excluded from token characters defined in [RFC2616]. Enumeration of:
ParameterPerRow (Reports are formatted with each parameter formatted as a row entry)
ParameterPerColumn (Reports are formatted with each parameter formatted as a column entry)

The format of the timestamp to use for data inserted into the row. Enumeration of:
Unix-Epoch (Timestamp is inserted using the UNIX epoch time (milliseconds since Jan 1, 1970 UTC) timestamp format. If the CPE is unable to acquire a time, then the time that has elapsed since the last reboot of the device is used)
ISO-8601 (Timestamp is inserted using the ISO-8601 timestamp format)
None (Timestamp is not inserted in the row)
This object defines the properties to be used when the {{object|##.Profile}} object's {{param|#.EncodingType}} parameter value is {{enum|JSON|##.EncodingTypes}}.

This parameter describes the formatting used for the report as described in {{template|BULK-DATA-JSON-REF}}. Note: This parameter is encoded as a token in the BBF-Report-Format header field and MUST NOT include spaces or other characters excluded from token characters defined in {{bibref|RFC2616}}.
The format of timestamp to use for the JSON Object named "CollectionTime" as described in {{template|BULK-DATA-JSON-REF}}.

This object defines the properties to be used when transporting bulk data using the HTTP/HTTPS protocol. This object is used when the {{param|#.Protocol}} parameter has a value of {{enum|HTTP|##.Protocols}}. For authentication purposes the CPE MUST support HTTP Basic and Digest Access Authentication as defined in {{bibref|RFC2616}}.
The URL for the collection server to receive the Bulk Data transmitted by the CPE.
Username used to authenticate the CPE when making a connection to the collection server.
Password used to authenticate the CPE when making a connection to the collection server.
Comma-separated list of strings. Indicates the HTTP Compression mechanism(s) supported by this CPE for the purposes of transferring bulk data.
The value of this parameter represents the HTTP Compression mechanism to be used by the CPE when transferring data to the collection server.
Comma-separated list of strings. Indicates the HTTP method(s) supported by this CPE for the purposes of transferring bulk data.
The value of this parameter represents the HTTP method to be used by the CPE when transferring data to the collection server.
When {{true}}, the CPE encodes the HTTP Date Header {{bibref|RFC2616|Section 14.18}} in the HTTP client request.
When {{true}}, the CPE retries unsuccessful attempts to transfer data.

Configures the data transfer retry wait interval, in seconds, as specified in {{template|BULK-DATA-HTTP-RETRY-REF}}. The device MUST use a random value between {{param}} and ({{param}} * {{param|RetryIntervalMultiplier}} / 1000) as the first retry wait interval. Other values in the retry pattern MUST be calculated using this value as a starting point.

Configures the retry interval multiplier as specified in {{template|BULK-DATA-HTTP-RETRY-REF}}. This value is expressed in units of 0.001. Hence the values of the multiplier range between 1.000 and 65.535. The device MUST use a random value between {{param|RetryMinimumWaitInterval}} and ({{param|RetryMinimumWaitInterval}} * {{param}} / 1000) as the first retry wait interval. Other values in the retry pattern MUST be calculated using this value as a starting point.
The number of entries in the RequestURIParameter table.

This object represents an instance of a parameter to be used in the report header used as part of the HTTP Request-URI transmitted by the CPE to the collection server using the Request-URI in addition to the parameters required by {{template|BULK-DATA-HTTP-QUERY-REF}}.
Name of the Request-URI parameter. If Name is an empty string, the name of the Request-URI parameter is the value of Reference.
The value MUST be the path name of a parameter to be used as the Request-URI parameter. If the value of this parameter is empty, then this object is not encoded in the report header.
FAST Line table (a stackable interface object as described in TR-181i2, Section 4.2). This table models physical FAST lines.
The number of entries in Line Table
FAST Line table (a stackable interface object as described in TR-181i2,Section 4.2). This table models physical FAST lines.
Enables or disables the FAST line. This parameter is based on ''ifAdminStatus'' from RFC2863.

The current operational state of the FAST line (see TR-181i2, Section 4.2.2). When Enabled is false, then Status SHOULD normally be Down or NotPresent or Error if there is a fault condition on the interface. When Enable is changed to true then Status SHOULD change to Up if and only if the interface is able to transmit and receive network traffic; it SHOULD change to Dormant if and only if the interface is operable but is waiting for external actions before it can transmit and receive network traffic (and subsequently change to Up if still operable when the expected actions have completed); it SHOULD change to LowerLayerDown if and only if the interface is prevented from entering the Up state because one or more of the interfaces beneath it is down; it SHOULD remain in the Error state if there is an error or other fault condition detected on the interface; it SHOULD remain in the NotPresent state if the interface has missing (typically hardware) components; it SHOULD change to Unknown if the state of the interface can not be determined for some reason. This parameter is based on ''ifOperStatus'' from RFC2863.

A non-volatile handle used to reference this instance. Alias provides a mechanism for an ACS to label this instance for future reference. An initial unique value MUST be assigned when the CPE creates an instance of this object.
The textual name of the FAST line as assigned by the CPE.
The accumulated time in sedonds since the FAST line entered its current operational state.
A timestamp, in seconds, of the last status change. Used to calculate the TR181 LastChange value.

Indicates the line number for bonding. Only 0 or 1 is allowed because we only bond 2 lines. This parameter is kept here for purpose of using the existing DSL API. Line 0 is for the physical line 0, and the other is the second FAST line.

Comma seperated list (maximum length 1024). Each list item must be the be the path name of an interface object that is stacked immediately below this interface object. If the referenced object is deleted, the corresponding item MUST be removed from the list. See Section 4.2.1 of TR-181i2.
Indicates whether the interface points towards the Internet (true) or towards End Devices (false)
A string identifying the version of the modem firmware currently installed for this interface. This is applicable only when the modem firmware is separable from the overall CPE software.

Status of the FAST physical link. When LinkStatus is Up, Status is expected to be Up. When LinkStatus is Initializing or EstablishingLink or NoSignal or Disabled, Status is expected to be Down. The Error value MAY be used by the CPE to indicate a locally defined error condition.
A list of items to indicate which FAST profiles are allowed on the line.
Indicates which FAST profile is currently in use on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_106a This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "106a" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_212a This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "212a" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_106b This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "106b" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_106c This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "106c" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_212c This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "212c" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_P424a This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "P424a" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_P424d This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "P424d" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_Q424c This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "Q424c" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_Q424d This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "Q424d" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_P424amp This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "P424amp" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_P424dmp This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "P424dmp" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_Q424cmp This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "Q424cmp" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_Q424dmp This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "Q424dmp" which is allowed on the line.
The power management state of the line. Enumeration of L0, L2.1, L2.2, L3. Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.9701.

The success failure cause of the initialization. An enumeration of the following integer values: *0: Successful * 1: Configuration error. This error occurs if the line cannot reach L0 state due to a mismatch of configuration and FTU capabilities. * 2: Configuration not feasible on the line. This error occurs if the line cannot reach the L0 state due to a mismatch of configuration of line and noise characteristics. * 3: Communication problem. This error occurs, for example, due to corrupted messages or bad syntax messages or if no common mode can be selected in the G.994.1 handshaking procedure or due to a timeout. * 4: No far-end FTU detected. This error occurs if the far-end FTU is not powered or not connected or if the line is too long to allow detection of a far-end FTU. * 5: Any other or unknown Initialization Failure cause. Note: In G.997.2, this parameter is called "Initialization success/failure cause". See Clause 7.20.2.1 of ITU-T Recommendation G.998.2.

This parameter reports the estimate of the electrical length expressed in 0.1 dB units, as determined by the FTU-R (see clause 7.3.1.4.2.1/ITU G.9701) and conveyed in the R-MSG1 initialization message (see clause 12.3.3.2.3 of G.9701). The value is coded as an unsignedInt in the range 0 (coded as 0) to 128 dB (coded as 1280) in steps of 0.1 dB. Note: This parameter is defined as UPBOKLE-R in Clause 7.10.4.2 of ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.

This parameter reports the downstream signal count of the last transmitted initialization signal in the last full or short initialization performed on the line. The valid values are 0..21. The downstream signal count is defined in clause 12.3.1 in ITU G.9701. Note: See clause 7.10.2.2 ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.

This parameter reports the upstream signal count of the last transmitted initialization signal in the last full or short initialization performed on the line. The valid values are 0..21. The upstream signal count is defined in clause 12.3.1 of ITU Recommendation G.9701. Note: See clause 7.10.2.3 ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.

This parameter reports the electrical length (in 0.1.dB unit) that would have been sent from the FTU-O to the FTU-R if the electrical length was not forced by the DPU-MIB. If the electrical length is not forced by the DPU-MIB, then this object reports the final electrical length, as determined by the FTU-O (see clause 7.3.1.4.2.1 of G.9701) and conveyed in the O-UPDATE initialization message (see clause 12.3.3.2.4 in G.9701). Note: See clause 7.10.4.1 in ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.
Signifies the line pair that the modem is using to connection. LineNumber = 1 is the innermost pair.

This parameter reports the attainable net data rate expressed in Kbps as defined in clause 11.4.1.1.2 in ITU Recommendation G.9701. Note: This parameter is related to the G.997.2 parameter ATTNDRus. See clause 7.11.2.1 ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.

This parameter reports the attainable net data rate expressed in Kbps as defined in clause 11.4.1.1.2 of ITU Recommendation G.9701. Note: This parameter is related to the G.997.2 parameter ATTNDRds. See clause 7.11.2.1 ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.

This parameter reports the signal-to-noise ratio margin (as defined in clause 9.8.3.2 of ITU Recommendation G.9701 and 11.4.1.3 of G.9701) in the upstream direction. A special value indicates that the signal-to-noise ratio margin is out of the range to be represented. The parameter is expressed in 0.1dB. Note: In G.997.2, this parameter is called SNRMus. See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.

This parameter reports the signal-to-noise ratio margin (as defined in clause 9.8.3.2 in ITU Recommendation G.9701 and 11.4.1.3 in G.9701) in the upstream direction. A special value indicates that the signal-to-noise ratio margin is out of the range to be represented. The parameter is expressed in 0.1dB. Note: In G.997.2, this parameter is called SNRMds. See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.
The current upstream signal loss (expressed in 0.1dB).
The current downstream signal loss (expressed in 0.1dB).
The current output power at the CPE's FAST line (expressed in 0.1dBmV).
The current received power at the CPE's DSL line (expressed in 0.1dBmV).

This parameter reports the signal-to-noise margin for the robust management channel (RMC) in the downstream direction (express in 0.1dB). A special value (-512) indicates that the signal-to-noise ratio margin for the RMC is out of the range to be represented. This parameter is defined in clauses 7.10.12.1 of ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.

This parameter reports the signal-to-noise margin for the robust management channel (RMC) in the upstream direction (express in 0.1dB). A special value (-512) indicates that the signal-to-noise ratio margin for the RMC is out of the range to be represented. This parameter is defined in clauses 7.10.12.2 of ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.

List items report the bit allocation values on RMC sub-carriers in RMC symbols in the downstream direction. Each pair composes of a sub-carrier index from 0..4095 and an 8 bit allocation value. There are maximum 512 pairs. This parameter is defined in clause 7.10.12.3 of ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.

List items report the bit allocation values on RMC sub-carriers in RMC symbols in the upstream direction. Each pair composes of a sub-carrier index from 0..4095 and an 8 bit allocation value. There are maximum 512 pairs. This parameter is defined in clause 7.10.12.4 of ITU-T Recommendation {{bibref|G.997.2}}.

This indicates whether FEXT cancellation in the downstream direction from all the other vectored lines into the line in the vectored group is enabled (TRUE) or disabled (FALSE). This parameter is defined as FEXT_TO_CANCEL_ENABLEds in clause 7.1.7.1 of ITU Recommendation G.997.2.

This indicates whether FEXT cancellation in the upstream direction from all the other vectored lines into the line in the vectored group is enabled (TRUE) or disabled (FALSE). This parameter is defined as FEXT_TO_CANCEL_ENABLEds in clause 7.1.7.1 of ITU Recommendation G.997.2.
This parameter reports the expected throughput rate expressed in Kbps as defined in clause 7.11.1.2 of ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2
This parameter reports the expected throughput rate expressed in Kbps as defined in clause 7.11.1.2 of ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2
This parameter reports the attainable expected throughput expressed in Kbps as defined in clause 7.11.2.2 of ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.
This parameter reports the attainable expected throughput expressed in Kbps as defined in clause 7.11.2.2 of ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.
This parameter reports the minimum error free throughput value expressed in Kbps computed from power up as defined in clause 11.4.1.1.3 of ITU-T Recommendation G.9701

Throughput statistics for this interface. The CPE MUST reset the interface's Stats parameters (unless otherwise stated in individual object or parameter descriptions) either when the interface becomes operationally down due to a previous administrative down (i.e. the interface's Status parameter transitions to a down state after the interface is disabled) or when the interface becomes administratively up (i.e. the interface's Enable parameter transitions from false to true). Administrative and operational interface status is discussed in TR-181i2,section 4.2.2.
The total number of bytes transmitted out of the interface, including framing characters.
The total number of bytes received on the interface, including framing characters.
The total number of packets transmitted out of the interface.
The total number of packets received on the interface.
The total number of outbound packets that could not be transmitted because of errors.
The total number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being delivered to a higher-layer protocol.

The total number of outbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being transmitted. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space.

The total number of inbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being delivered. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space.
The total number of eoc bytes sent. Refer to ITU-T Rec. G.9701.
The total number of eoc bytes received. Refer to ITU-T Rec. G.9701.
The total number of eoc packets sent. Refer to ITU-T Rec. G.9701.
The total number of eoc packets received. Refer to ITU-T Rec. G.9701.
The total number of eoc messages sent. Refer to ITU-T Rec. G.9701.
The total number of eoc messages received. Refer to ITU-T Rec. G.9701.

FAST-specific statistic. The Number of seconds since the beginning of the period used for collection of Device.Line.{i}.Stats.Total statistics. Statistics SHOULD continue to be accumulated across CPE reboots, though this might not always be possible. Note: TotalStart SHOULD NOT be reset when the interface statistics are reset via an interface disable / enable cycle.

FAST-specific statistic. The Number of seconds since the most recent DSL Showtime - the beginning of the period used for collection of Showtime statistics. Showtime is defined as successful completion of the DSL link establishment process. The ''Showtime'' statistics are those collected since the most recent establishment of the DSL link. Note: ShowtimeStart SHOULD NOT be reset when the interface statistics are reset via an interface disable / enable cycle.

FAST-specific statistic. The Number of seconds since the second most recent DSL Showtime-the beginning of the period used for collection of LastShowtime statistics. If the CPE has not retained information about the second most recent Showtime (e.g., on reboot), the start of ''LastShowtime'' statistics MAY temporarily coincide with the start of ''Showtime'' statistics. Note: LastShowtimeStart SHOULD NOT be reset when the interface statistics are reset via an interface disable / enable cycle.

FAST-specific statistic. The Number of seconds since the beginning of the period used for collection of CurrentDay statistics. The CPE MAY align the beginning of each ''CurrentDay'' interval with days in the UTC time zone, but is not required to do so. Statistics SHOULD continue to be accumulated across CPE reboots, though this might not always be possible. Note: CurrentDayStart SHOULD NOT be reset when the interface statistics are reset via an interface disable / enable cycle.

FAST-specific statistic. The Number of seconds since the beginning of the period used for collection of QuarterHour statistics. The CPE MAY align the beginning of each ''QuarterHour'' interval with real-time quarter-hour intervals, but is not required to do so. Statistics SHOULD continue to be accumulated across CPE reboots, though this might not always be possible. Note: QuarterHourStart SHOULD NOT be reset when the interface statistics are reset via an interface disable / enable cycle.
This object contains FAST line total statistics. Note: The Stats.Total. parameters SHOULD NOT be reset when the interface statistics are reset via an interface disable / enable cycle.

Total number of errored seconds as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.2. An errored second (ES) is declared if, during a 1-second interval, there are one or more crc anomalies, or one or more los defects, or one or more lor defects, or one or more lpr primitives.
Total number of severely errored seconds as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.2.
Total number of loss of signal seconds (LOSS) as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.2. A LOSS is declared if, during a 1-second interval, there are one or more los defects.
Total number of loss of RMC seconds (LORS) as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.2. A LORS is declared if, during a 1-second interval, there are one or more lor defects.
Total number of unavailable seconds (UAS) as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.2. Total number of unavailable seconds (UAS)
This parameter reports a count of uncorrected DTU anomalies (rtx_uc). This parameter is defined in clause 7.8.5 of ITU-T Rec. G.997.2.
This parameter reports a count of retransmitted DTU anomalies (rtx_tx). This parameter is defined in clause 7.8.6 of ITU-T Rec. G.997.2.
This parameter reports a count of the successful bit swap (BSW) primitives. This parameter is defined as success_BSW in clause 7.7.20 of ITU-T Rec. {{bibref|G.997.2}}.
This parameter reports a count of the successful autonomous SRA (seamless rate adaptation) primitives. This parameter is defined as success_SRA in clause 7.7.21 of ITU-T Rec. G.997.2.
This parameter reports a count of the successful FRA (fast rate adaptation) primitives. This parameter is defined as success_FRA in clause 7.7.22 of ITU-T Rec. G.997.2.
This parameter reports a count of the successful RPA (RMC parameter adjustment) primitives. This parameter is defined as success_RPA in clause 7.7.23 of ITU-T Rec. G.997.2.
This parameter reports a count of the successful TIGA (transmitter initiated gain adjustment) primitives. This parameter is defined as success_TIGA in clause 7.7.24 of ITU-T Rec. G.997.2.

This object contains FAST line statistics accumulated since the most recent FAST Showtime. See G.997.1,Chapter 7.2.6. Note: This object's parameters SHOULD NOT be reset when the interface statistics are reset via an interface disable/enable cycle.

Total number of errored seconds as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.2. An errored second (ES) is declared if, during a 1-second interval, there are one or more crc anomalies, or one or more los defects, or one or more lor defects, or one or more lpr primitives.
Total number of severely errored seconds as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.2.

Total number of loss of RMC seconds (LORS) as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.2. A LORS is declared if, during a 1-second interval, there are one or more lor defects.
Total number of unavailable seconds (UAS) as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.2. Total number of unavailable seconds (UAS)

This parameter reports a count of the successful bit swap (BSW) primitives. This parameter is defined as success_BSW in clause 7.7.20 of ITU-T Rec. {{bibref|G.997.2}}.
This parameter reports a count of the successful autonomous SRA (seamless rate adaptation) primitives. This parameter is defined as success_SRA in clause 7.7.21 of ITU-T Rec. G.997.2.

This parameter reports a count of the successful TIGA (transmitter initiated gain adjustment) primitives. This parameter is defined as success_TIGA in clause 7.7.24 of ITU-T Rec. G.997.2.

This object contains FAST line statistics accumulated since the second most recent FAST Showtime. See G.997.1,Chapter 7.2.6. Note: The object's parameters SHOULD NOT be reset when the interface statistics are reset via an interface disable/enable cycle.

Total number of errored seconds as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.2. An errored second (ES) is declared if, during a 1-second interval, there are one or more crc anomalies, or one or more los defects, or one or more lor defects, or one or more lpr primitives.
Total number of severely errored seconds as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.2.
Total number of loss of signal seconds (LOSS) as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.2. A LOSS is declared if, during a 1-second interval, there are one or more los defects.

This parameter reports a count of the successful TIGA (transmitter initiated gain adjustment) primitives. This parameter is defined as success_TIGA in clause 7.7.24 of ITU-T Rec. G.997.2.

This object contains FAST line statistics accumulated during the current day. See G.997.1,Chapter 7.2.6. Note: The CurrentDay. parameters SHOULD NOT be reset when the interface statistics are reset via an interface disable / enable cycle.

Total number of errored seconds as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.2. An errored second (ES) is declared if, during a 1-second interval, there are one or more crc anomalies, or one or more los defects, or one or more lor defects, or one or more lpr primitives.

Total number of errored seconds as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.2. An errored second (ES) is declared if, during a 1-second interval, there are one or more crc anomalies, or one or more los defects, or one or more lor defects, or one or more lpr primitives.

This object contains the FAST line test parameters that are available during the L0 (i.e., Showtime) state.

Reports the number of sub-carriers in any one sub-carrier group used to represent the downstream SNR(f) values. Valid values are 1, 2, 4, and 8. See clause 7.10.8.2 ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2. Note: In ITU-T G.9701-2014, the only valid value is G = 1.

Reports the number of sub-carriers in any one sub-carrier group used to represent the upstream SNR(f) values. Valid values are 1, 2, 4, and 8. See clause 7.10.8.5 ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2. Note: In ITU-T G.9701-2014, the only valid value is G = 1.

Comma-separated values (maximum list length is 2047) of integers. Reports the downstream SNR(f) values. A special value indicates that no measurement could be done for this sub-carrier group because it is out of the downstream MEDLEY set or its transmit power is zero. The number of elements will depend on the value of SNRGds. Interpretation of the values is as defined in clause 11.4.1.2.2.of ITU-T Rec. G.9701. Note: See also clause 7.10.8.3 of ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.

Comma-separated values (maximum list length is 2047) of integers. Reports the upstream SNR(f) values. A special value indicates that no measurement could be done for this sub-carrier group because it is out of the downstream MEDLEY set or its transmit power is zero. The number of elements will depend on the value of SNRGds. Interpretation of the values is as defined in clause 11.4.1.2.2.of ITU-T Rec. G.9701. Note: See also clause 7.10.8.6 of ITU-T Recommendation G.997.2.
